name: Gyokuro
description: Japan's most prized shade-grown green tea with intense umami sweetness.
about: Gyokuro is Japan's highest grade of green tea, shaded for 20+ days before harvest. This process increases chlorophyll and L-theanine, creating an intensely sweet, umami-rich tea with reduced astringency.
tastingNotes: Intense umami, sweet marine notes, asparagus, nori seaweed, and lingering sweetness.
history: Gyokuro was first produced in 1835 in Uji by Yamamoto Kahei. The shading technique was discovered to produce sweeter, more delicate leaves.
servingRecommendation: Use cooler water (50-60°C) and steep for 2-3 minutes. Multiple infusions reveal different flavor layers. Serve in small cups.

name: Ceremonial Matcha
description: The finest grade of stone-ground green tea for traditional Japanese tea ceremony.
about: Ceremonial matcha is made from the youngest, most tender tea leaves, shade-grown and stone-ground into a fine powder. It represents the pinnacle of Japanese tea culture.
tastingNotes: Creamy umami, vegetal sweetness, subtle bitterness, and lingering finish.
history: Matcha was introduced to Japan from China by Zen monk Eisai in 1191. The tea ceremony (chanoyu) developed around matcha in the 15th-16th centuries.
servingRecommendation: Sift 1-2g of matcha, add 70ml hot water, and whisk vigorously with a chasen (bamboo whisk) until frothy.

name: Sencha
description: Japan's most popular everyday green tea with refreshing, grassy character.
about: Sencha accounts for about 80% of Japanese tea production. The leaves are steamed after harvest to halt oxidation, then rolled and dried, creating a distinctively fresh, vegetal flavor.
tastingNotes: Fresh grass, spinach, mild sweetness, and subtle astringency with clean finish.
history: Sencha production began in Uji in 1738 when Nagatani Soen developed the steaming and rolling method that defines Japanese green tea.
servingRecommendation: Brew at 70-80°C for 1-2 minutes. Can be enjoyed multiple infusions with slightly increasing temperature.

name: Genmaicha
type: Japanese Green Tea with Roasted Rice
description: A comforting blend of green tea and toasted rice with nutty, popcorn-like flavor.
about: Genmaicha combines sencha or bancha with roasted brown rice (genmai). Originally created to stretch expensive tea, it's now beloved for its toasty, comforting character.
tastingNotes: Toasted rice, popcorn, nutty sweetness, and light vegetal notes.
history: Genmaicha originated as a way to make tea affordable for common people by adding rice as a filler. It became popular across all social classes.
servingRecommendation: Brew with hot water (80-85°C) for 2-3 minutes. Excellent as an everyday tea, especially with meals.

name: Hojicha
description: A roasted Japanese green tea with warm, caramel-like character and low caffeine.
about: Hojicha is made by roasting bancha or sencha over high heat, giving it a distinctive reddish-brown color and toasty flavor. The roasting reduces caffeine, making it ideal for evenings.
tastingNotes: Roasted nuts, caramel, woody notes, and subtle smokiness with no astringency.
history: Hojicha was created in Kyoto in the 1920s as a way to utilize older tea leaves and stems. It quickly became popular for its soothing character.
servingRecommendation: Brew with boiling water for a quick steep. The roasted character tolerates high temperatures well. Great served hot or iced.

name: Dragon Well (Longjing)
description: China's most famous green tea, pan-fired to create a distinctive flat leaf and chestnut aroma.
about: Longjing (Dragon Well) is China's most prestigious green tea, grown near West Lake in Hangzhou. The leaves are hand-pressed flat during pan-firing, creating a unique appearance and nutty sweetness.
tastingNotes: Chestnut, fresh grass, sweet vegetal notes, and subtle orchid fragrance.
history: Longjing has been produced since the Tang Dynasty (618-907 CE). It became an imperial tribute tea during the Qing Dynasty and remains one of China's Ten Famous Teas.
servingRecommendation: Brew in a glass to watch the beautiful flat leaves unfurl. Use 75-80°C water and steep 2-3 minutes. Multiple infusions recommended.

name: Biluochun
description: A delicate Chinese green tea with distinctive spiral-rolled leaves and fruity aroma.
about: Biluochun (Green Snail Spring) is named for its tightly spiraled leaves. Traditionally grown among fruit trees, the tea absorbs floral and fruity notes from peach, plum, and apricot blossoms.
tastingNotes: Fruity florals, fresh chestnut, light vegetal notes, and sweet finish.
history: Biluochun dates to the Tang Dynasty but gained its current name from Emperor Kangxi during the Qing Dynasty, who was impressed by its snail-like appearance.
servingRecommendation: Use cooler water (70-75°C) to preserve delicate flavors. Watch the tiny spiraled leaves sink in a glass cup.

name: Gunpowder Green
description: A bold Chinese green tea with leaves rolled into small pellets resembling gunpowder.
about: Gunpowder tea gets its name from its appearance—leaves tightly rolled into small pellets. This rolling helps preserve freshness and creates a stronger, more robust flavor than other green teas.
tastingNotes: Bold, slightly smoky, vegetal with hints of honey and a brisk finish.
history: Gunpowder tea has been produced since the Tang Dynasty. It became popular in Morocco for making mint tea and is one of the most widely consumed teas globally.
servingRecommendation: Brew at 75-80°C for 2-3 minutes. Traditional Moroccan preparation includes fresh mint and sugar. Also excellent plain.

name: Darjeeling First Flush
description: The 'Champagne of Teas' - a delicate, floral spring harvest from the Himalayan foothills.
about: First flush Darjeeling is the first spring harvest, picked in March-April. The cool mountain climate and unique terroir create a light, floral tea unlike any other black tea.
tastingNotes: Muscatel grape, floral notes, light astringency, and fresh spring character.
history: Tea cultivation began in Darjeeling in 1841. The region's unique combination of altitude, rainfall, and soil creates tea found nowhere else on Earth.
servingRecommendation: Brew at 85-90°C for 3-4 minutes. Best enjoyed without milk to appreciate the delicate muscatel notes.

name: Darjeeling Second Flush
description: A richer summer harvest Darjeeling with pronounced muscatel character.
about: Second flush Darjeeling is harvested in May-June after the first monsoon rains. The warmer weather creates a more developed, muscatel flavor that many consider the quintessential Darjeeling experience.
tastingNotes: Pronounced muscatel grape, honey, ripe fruit, and amber liquor with fuller body.
history: The muscatel character of second flush Darjeeling became highly prized in British tea culture. It remains one of the most sought-after teas in the world.
servingRecommendation: Brew at 90-95°C for 3-5 minutes. Can be enjoyed with a small splash of milk, though many prefer it black.

name: Assam Orthodox
description: A bold, malty Indian black tea from the world's largest tea-growing region.
about: Assam produces more tea than any other region in the world. Orthodox Assam is made using traditional methods, creating a bold, full-bodied tea with distinctive malty sweetness.
tastingNotes: Bold malt, honey, dried fruit, and brisk character with rich amber color.
history: Tea was discovered growing wild in Assam in 1823. The Assam tea plant (Camellia sinensis var. assamica) is a different variety from Chinese tea, producing stronger, maltier flavors.
servingRecommendation: Brew with boiling water for 3-5 minutes. Excellent with milk and sugar for a traditional British-style breakfast tea.

name: Ceylon Orange Pekoe
description: A bright, citrusy high-grown Ceylon tea with refined character.
about: Ceylon Orange Pekoe refers to high-quality whole-leaf tea from Sri Lanka's highland estates. The high altitude creates a bright, crisp tea with natural citrus notes.
tastingNotes: Bright citrus, crisp tannins, subtle floral notes, and clean finish.
history: Ceylon tea production began in the 1860s after coffee blight destroyed Sri Lanka's coffee plantations. It became one of the world's most recognized tea origins.
servingRecommendation: Brew with boiling water for 3-4 minutes. Excellent with lemon or enjoyed black. Also good with a splash of milk.

name: Keemun
description: China's most famous black tea with complex wine-like character and orchid notes.
about: Keemun (Qimen) is regarded as one of China's finest black teas. It was developed in 1875 to compete with Indian teas and quickly became prized for its unique, complex character.
tastingNotes: Wine-like complexity, orchid fragrance, pine, dried fruit, and smooth finish.
history: Keemun was created in 1875 by Yu Ganchen, who studied black tea production in Fujian. It became the base for English Breakfast blends and remains one of China's Ten Famous Teas.
servingRecommendation: Brew at 90-95°C for 3-5 minutes. Best enjoyed without milk to appreciate the complex aromatics.

name: Lapsang Souchong
description: The world's first black tea, famously smoked over pine wood for intense smoky flavor.
about: Lapsang Souchong is traditionally smoked over pine wood fires, creating an intensely smoky flavor. It originated in the Wuyi Mountains and is considered the original black tea.
tastingNotes: Pine smoke, campfire, dried longan fruit, and whiskey-like notes.
history: Legend says Lapsang Souchong was created accidentally when tea farmers dried leaves over pine fires to speed processing. It became popular in Europe in the 17th century.
servingRecommendation: Brew with boiling water for 3-5 minutes. The smoky flavor is polarizing—try it before buying large quantities. Some enjoy it with milk.

name: Earl Grey
description: The classic bergamot-scented black tea blend named after a British Prime Minister.
about: Earl Grey is black tea flavored with oil of bergamot, a citrus fruit. The exact origin is debated, but it became one of the world's most popular flavored teas.
tastingNotes: Bergamot citrus, floral lavender hints, malty base, and aromatic finish.
history: Earl Grey is named after Charles Grey, 2nd Earl Grey, British Prime Minister 1830-1834. The story goes that the blend was created by a Chinese mandarin.
servingRecommendation: Brew with boiling water for 3-5 minutes. Traditional to enjoy with lemon rather than milk, which can curdle with bergamot.

name: English Breakfast
description: A robust, full-bodied blend designed to accompany a hearty English breakfast.
about: English Breakfast is a blend typically combining Assam, Ceylon, and Kenyan teas. It was created to be a strong, robust tea that pairs well with the traditional full English breakfast.
tastingNotes: Robust malty character, honey notes, brisk tannins, and full body.
history: English Breakfast tea emerged in the 19th century as British tea culture developed. The exact origins are disputed, but it became synonymous with British tea drinking.
servingRecommendation: Brew with boiling water for 3-5 minutes. Traditionally served with milk and sugar. Strong enough to handle both.

name: Irish Breakfast
description: An exceptionally strong blend dominated by Assam, perfect with milk.
about: Irish Breakfast is even stronger than English Breakfast, with a higher proportion of robust Assam tea. The Irish are among the world's largest tea consumers per capita.
tastingNotes: Very robust malt, strong tannins, rich honey notes, and deep red-brown color.
history: Irish Breakfast developed as a stronger alternative to English Breakfast. Ireland's damp climate and hearty cuisine called for a more robust tea.
servingRecommendation: Brew with boiling water for 4-5 minutes. Almost always served with milk and sugar in Ireland.

name: Golden Yunnan
description: A luxurious Chinese black tea with golden tips and honeyed sweetness.
about: Golden Yunnan (Dian Hong) features abundant golden tips from young tea buds. Yunnan's ancient tea trees and unique climate produce a distinctively smooth, sweet black tea.
tastingNotes: Honey, cocoa, malt, dried fruit, and smooth finish with minimal astringency.
history: Yunnan black tea production began in 1939 as China sought new export products. The region's ancient tea trees create unique, prized flavors.
servingRecommendation: Brew at 90-95°C for 3-4 minutes. Best enjoyed without milk to appreciate the natural sweetness and complexity.

name: Tie Guan Yin (Iron Goddess)
description: China's most famous oolong, named after the Buddhist goddess of mercy.
about: Tie Guan Yin is a premium oolong from Anxi, Fujian. The traditional preparation involves multiple rounds of rolling and oxidation, creating complex floral and roasted notes.
tastingNotes: Orchid fragrance, creamy texture, roasted notes, and lingering floral sweetness.
history: Tie Guan Yin's origin involves legends of the goddess Guan Yin appearing to a farmer. It has been produced since the 18th century and is one of China's Ten Famous Teas.
servingRecommendation: Use gongfu style: small teapot, short steeps (1-2 min), many infusions. Watch the tightly rolled leaves unfurl beautifully.

name: Da Hong Pao (Big Red Robe)
description: A legendary rock oolong with mineral complexity and roasted character.
about: Da Hong Pao is one of the most famous and expensive teas in the world. The original mother trees on Wuyi Mountain are national treasures. Modern Da Hong Pao is made from cuttings of these trees.
tastingNotes: Mineral rock essence, roasted grain, dried fruit, orchid, and long-lasting hui gan (returning sweetness).
history: Legend says Da Hong Pao cured a Ming Dynasty scholar's mother, and he draped his red robe over the tea bushes in gratitude. The original bushes are among the world's most valuable plants.
servingRecommendation: Gongfu brewing recommended. Use boiling water, short steeps. Can handle 10+ infusions, revealing different flavors each time.

name: Wuyi Rou Gui (Cinnamon)
description: A bold Wuyi rock oolong with distinctive cinnamon-like spice character.
about: Rou Gui is a Wuyi rock oolong prized for its naturally spicy, cinnamon-like character. The mineral-rich rocky terroir creates a distinctive 'rock rhyme' (yan yun) flavor.
tastingNotes: Cinnamon spice, roasted grain, stone fruit, mineral notes, and warming finish.
history: Rou Gui has been grown in the Wuyi Mountains for centuries. It gained prominence in the 19th century as one of the primary Wuyi cultivars.
servingRecommendation: Gongfu brewing with boiling water. Short steeps (30-60 seconds initially) allow multiple infusions revealing evolving flavors.

name: Dong Ding (Frozen Peak)
description: A classic Taiwanese oolong with traditional roasted character and smooth sweetness.
about: Dong Ding is Taiwan's most famous traditional oolong, grown on Frozen Peak Mountain. The combination of ball-rolling and roasting creates a uniquely smooth, complex tea.
tastingNotes: Roasted grain, caramel sweetness, stone fruit, and subtle floral notes with silky texture.
history: Dong Ding was brought to Taiwan from Wuyi in the 1850s. It became the foundation of Taiwan's famous oolong tradition.
servingRecommendation: Gongfu brewing recommended. Tightly rolled leaves need hot water (90-95°C) and open up over multiple infusions.

name: Ali Shan High Mountain
description: A floral, butter-smooth high mountain oolong from Taiwan's famous Ali Shan range.
about: Ali Shan is one of Taiwan's premier high mountain tea regions, producing oolongs above 1,000m altitude. The cool climate and mist create exceptionally smooth, floral teas.
tastingNotes: Buttery cream, orchid, lily, fresh vegetables, and sweet finish.
history: High mountain oolong production began in Taiwan in the 1970s and 1980s. Ali Shan became synonymous with premium Taiwanese tea.
servingRecommendation: Gongfu brewing with 90-95°C water. The tightly rolled balls need multiple short infusions to fully unfurl. 6-8 infusions possible.

name: Oriental Beauty (Bai Hao)
description: A unique heavily oxidized oolong with honey-fruit character from insect-bitten leaves.
about: Oriental Beauty is made from leaves bitten by tiny leafhoppers. The plant's defensive response creates unique honey and muscatel notes. It's one of the most heavily oxidized oolongs.
tastingNotes: Honey, muscatel grape, ripe peach, rose, and spice with silky texture.
history: Oriental Beauty's name supposedly came from Queen Elizabeth II, who remarked on its beauty. The insect-bite process was discovered accidentally by Taiwanese farmers.
servingRecommendation: Brew at 85-90°C for 3-5 minutes. Can be brewed Western or gongfu style. Beautiful leaf appearance in clear glass.

name: Jin Xuan (Milk Oolong)
description: A modern Taiwanese cultivar with natural creamy, milky character.
about: Jin Xuan is a cultivar developed in Taiwan in the 1980s. It naturally produces a creamy, milky flavor and aroma without any added flavoring, though artificially flavored versions exist.
tastingNotes: Natural cream and milk notes, floral orchid, butter, and sweet finish.
history: Jin Xuan (TTES #12) was developed at Taiwan's Tea Research Station in 1981. Its natural milky character made it internationally popular.
servingRecommendation: Gongfu brewing at 90-95°C. Look for authentic Jin Xuan without artificial flavoring—the natural creaminess is subtle but distinctive.

name: Bai Mu Dan (White Peony)
description: A beautiful white tea with silvery leaves and gentle floral-honey character.
about: Bai Mu Dan (White Peony) is made from one bud and two leaves. It offers more body than Silver Needle while retaining the delicate character of white tea.
tastingNotes: Hay, honey, melon, peach, and gentle floral notes with light body.
history: White tea production in Fujian dates to the Tang Dynasty. Bai Mu Dan became a standard grade below Silver Needle, offering excellent quality at accessible prices.
servingRecommendation: Brew at 75-85°C for 3-5 minutes. Multiple infusions possible. Best appreciated in a clear glass to see the beautiful leaves.

name: Bai Hao Yin Zhen (Silver Needle)
description: The most prized white tea, made only from unopened tea buds covered in silvery down.
about: Silver Needle is the highest grade of white tea, made exclusively from spring buds covered in fine white hairs. It's minimally processed, simply withered and dried.
tastingNotes: Subtle honey, fresh cucumber, melon, hay, and delicate sweetness with silky texture.
history: Silver Needle has been produced since the late 18th century. It was traditionally reserved for nobility and remains one of China's most prestigious teas.
servingRecommendation: Use cooler water (70-80°C) and longer steep times. Watch the beautiful silver buds float vertically in glass. Multiple infusions reveal subtle changes.

name: Shou Mei (Longevity Eyebrow)
description: A rustic white tea with fuller body and more developed flavor.
about: Shou Mei is made from mature leaves harvested later in the season. It offers more body and complexity than other white teas at an accessible price point.
tastingNotes: Dried fruit, honey, autumn leaves, and subtle woodiness with fuller body.
history: Shou Mei developed as a way to utilize mature leaves that didn't meet Silver Needle or White Peony standards. It became appreciated in its own right.
servingRecommendation: More forgiving than delicate white teas. Brew at 85-95°C for 3-5 minutes. Can handle multiple infusions.

name: Moonlight White (Yue Guang Bai)
description: A distinctive Yunnan white tea with large, dramatic leaves and honey sweetness.
about: Moonlight White is made from Yunnan's large-leaf tea trees using white tea processing. The leaves have distinctive black and white coloring, said to resemble moonlight.
tastingNotes: Honey, apricot, hay, rose, and subtle malt with silky texture.
history: Moonlight White is a relatively recent creation, developed as Yunnan tea makers applied white tea techniques to local large-leaf tea trees.
servingRecommendation: Brew at 80-90°C for 3-5 minutes. The dramatic leaves are beautiful in a glass pot. Good for multiple infusions.

name: Sheng Pu-erh (Raw)
description: A living tea that transforms over decades of aging from bright to deep and complex.
about: Sheng (raw) pu-erh is made from sun-dried tea leaves and naturally ferments over time. Young sheng is bright and astringent; aged sheng becomes smooth, complex, and highly prized.
tastingNotes: Young: bitter, floral, hay. Aged: smooth, camphor, dried fruit, leather, complex sweetness.
history: Pu-erh originated in Yunnan's Pu'er County over 2,000 years ago. It was traded along the Tea Horse Road and traditionally compressed for transport.
servingRecommendation: Gongfu brewing essential. Rinse leaves, then brew with boiling water for short steeps (15-30 seconds). Can yield 15+ infusions.

name: Shou Pu-erh (Ripe)
description: An accelerated-fermentation pu-erh with deep, earthy character and smooth body.
about: Shou (ripe) pu-erh undergoes a pile-fermentation process developed in the 1970s to replicate the character of aged sheng. It's dark, smooth, and earthy from the start.
tastingNotes: Earth, forest floor, dried dates, mushroom, and smooth sweetness.
history: The shou pu-erh process was developed in Kunming in 1973 to meet demand for 'aged' pu-erh. It democratized access to pu-erh's smooth, aged character.
servingRecommendation: Gongfu brewing recommended. Rinse leaves first, then short steeps with boiling water. Excellent digestive after meals.

name: Chamomile
description: A soothing, caffeine-free herbal with apple-like sweetness and calming properties.
about: Chamomile is one of the world's most popular herbal teas, made from dried flowers of the chamomile plant. It's been used for thousands of years for its calming and digestive benefits.
tastingNotes: Apple-like sweetness, honey, hay, floral notes, and gentle bitterness.
history: Chamomile has been used medicinally since ancient Egypt. The name comes from Greek meaning 'earth apple' for its apple-like scent.
servingRecommendation: Brew with boiling water for 5-10 minutes. Cover while steeping to retain volatile oils. Excellent with honey before bed.

name: Peppermint
description: A refreshing, cooling herbal tea with natural digestive benefits.
about: Peppermint tea is made from dried peppermint leaves, a hybrid of watermint and spearmint. It's prized for its refreshing flavor and digestive properties.
tastingNotes: Cool menthol, sweet mint, refreshing finish, and natural sweetness.
history: Peppermint was first cultivated in England in the late 17th century. It quickly became popular for both culinary and medicinal uses.
servingRecommendation: Brew with boiling water for 5-7 minutes. Excellent after meals for digestion. Can be enjoyed hot or iced.

name: Rooibos (Red Bush)
description: A naturally sweet, caffeine-free South African herbal with vanilla-honey notes.
about: Rooibos is made from the fermented leaves of Aspalathus linearis, a plant native to South Africa's Cederberg region. It's naturally caffeine-free and rich in antioxidants.
tastingNotes: Vanilla, honey, woody notes, subtle caramel, and natural sweetness.
history: Rooibos has been used by the indigenous Khoisan people for centuries. Commercial cultivation began in the 1930s, and it gained international popularity in the late 20th century.
servingRecommendation: Brew with boiling water for 5-7 minutes. Can't be overbrewed—won't become bitter. Excellent with milk and honey like black tea.

name: Hibiscus
description: A tart, ruby-red herbal tea made from dried hibiscus flowers.
about: Hibiscus tea is made from dried hibiscus sabdariffa flowers. It's known for its brilliant red color, tart cranberry-like flavor, and potential health benefits.
tastingNotes: Tart cranberry, pomegranate, floral notes, and bright acidity.
history: Hibiscus tea has been consumed for centuries across Africa, the Middle East, the Caribbean, and Latin America. It's known by many names including agua de jamaica.
servingRecommendation: Brew with boiling water for 5-10 minutes. Excellent hot or iced. Often sweetened with honey or sugar to balance tartness.

name: Ginger
description: A warming, spicy herbal tea made from fresh or dried ginger root.
about: Ginger tea is made from the rhizome of the ginger plant. It's been used for thousands of years in Asian medicine for its warming and digestive properties.
tastingNotes: Warm spice, peppery heat, citrus notes, and natural sweetness.
history: Ginger originated in Southeast Asia and spread along ancient trade routes. It has been used in traditional Chinese and Ayurvedic medicine for millennia.
servingRecommendation: Brew with boiling water for 5-10 minutes. Excellent with honey and lemon. Fresh ginger makes a stronger, spicier tea than dried.

name: Yerba Mate
description: A caffeinated South American herb with grassy, earthy character and energizing properties.
about: Yerba mate is made from the leaves of Ilex paraguariensis. It's the national drink of Argentina and contains caffeine, providing energy without the jitters of coffee.
tastingNotes: Grassy, vegetal, slightly bitter, earthy, and tobacco-like notes.
history: Yerba mate was consumed by the indigenous Guaraní people. Spanish colonizers adopted the drink, and it became central to South American culture.
servingRecommendation: Traditional preparation uses a gourd (mate) and metal straw (bombilla). Can also be brewed like tea. Don't use boiling water—it creates bitterness.

name: Masala Chai
description: India's beloved spiced milk tea with warming spices and bold black tea base.
about: Masala chai combines strong black tea with a blend of spices including cardamom, cinnamon, ginger, cloves, and black pepper. It's traditionally simmered with milk and sweetened.
tastingNotes: Warm spices, cardamom, ginger heat, cinnamon sweetness, and creamy body.
history: Masala chai developed in India, likely influenced by British tea culture and Ayurvedic traditions. It became the ubiquitous street drink sold by chai wallahs.
servingRecommendation: Simmer tea and spices in milk and water, sweeten to taste. Each family has their own spice blend. Best enjoyed hot and sweet.

name: Jasmine Dragon Pearls
description: Hand-rolled green tea pearls scented multiple times with fresh jasmine blossoms.
about: Jasmine Dragon Pearls are made by hand-rolling green tea leaves and repeatedly scenting them with fresh jasmine flowers. The pearls unfurl beautifully when brewed.
tastingNotes: Heady jasmine fragrance, sweet floral notes, fresh green tea base, and lingering aroma.
history: Jasmine tea originated during the Song Dynasty (960-1279). The scenting process involves layering tea with fresh jasmine flowers multiple times.
servingRecommendation: Brew in glass to watch pearls unfurl. Use 75-85°C water for 2-3 minutes. Multiple infusions reveal evolving jasmine and green tea character.

name: Pu-erh Mini Tuo Cha
description: Convenient single-serving pu-erh compressed into small bird's nest shapes.
about: Mini tuo cha are small compressed pu-erh portions, perfect for single servings. They make enjoying pu-erh convenient without breaking apart larger cakes.
tastingNotes: Earthy, smooth, dried dates, subtle sweetness, and clean finish.
history: Tuo cha (bowl-shaped tea) was developed for easy transport along the Tea Horse Road. Mini tuo cha are a modern convenience format.
servingRecommendation: Use one mini tuo per session. Rinse first, then brew with boiling water for short steeps. Good for gongfu or grandpa style brewing.

name: Formosa Oolong
description: A classic Taiwanese oolong representing the traditional art of Taiwan tea making.
about: Formosa Oolong refers to traditional Taiwanese oolongs, named after the Portuguese word for Taiwan ('Beautiful Island'). These teas showcase Taiwan's unique terroir and processing expertise.
tastingNotes: Floral orchid, creamy texture, light honey, and subtle toasted notes.
history: Taiwan began producing oolong in the 19th century with techniques brought from Fujian. The island developed its own distinctive styles and cultivars.
servingRecommendation: Gongfu or Western brewing both work well. Use 90-95°C water. Multiple infusions reveal the tea's complexity.
